text: Tata Steel in Port Talbot drowning under
a wave of cheap imports and struggling
to cope with EU climate policies and
high energy prices critics said that
story is shifting somewhat first the
UK's climate change committee calculated
that climate policies had raised Tatas
costs but only by one or maybe two
percent and how it seems tatter got a
windfall of 700 million pounds after
being given free pollution permits under
EU climate policy one analyst says Tatas
true windfall across Europe is double
that at 1.4 billion pounds cement firms
and oil firms also benefited from
valuable free pollution permits because
politicians were trying to shield them
from global competition critics say
they'd asked for more free pollution
permits than they knew they really
needed that doesn't break the rules but
there is anger that the system allowed
such huge windfall profits this
undermines the incentive of these
companies to invest in low-carbon
technologies and increase their
efficiency and it also undermines the
overall aim of our climate instruments
which is to cut pollution Tata was asked
to comment on its windfall profits a few
days ago but still has made no comment
BBC news understands that informally
it's telling people it can't be blamed
for profiting because the allocation of
carbon permits was too generous Rodger
Harbin BBC news
